Kelsey Ball

▲ About:

  • I studied at The University of Texas at Austin where I earned a B.S. in Electrical and Computer Engineering in May 2017. My focus was in machine learning and natural language processing. I just completed a Fulbright grant in Hyderabad, India, working on core NLP problems for low-resource Indian languages.

▼ Projects:

  • Texas 4000 for Cancer

    • I co-led a team of 25 students cycling over 4,000 miles from Austin, TX to Anchorage, AK. We raised over $800,000 for cancer research and support services, making us the highest fundraising team in the organization's history.

    • Learn more about or see footage of the journey.

  • Longhorn Stream Team

    • I helped form a citizen-science initiative at UT. We paddle rivers and collect water quality data to promote water conservation.

    • We also volunteer in the community by teaching environmental science to kids, and some of our members are involved in active research. See more of what we do.

▼ Work Experience:

  • Software Development Intern | Summer 2015

  • Qualcomm Inc.

    • Built and integrated an internal testing tool to track optimized kernel parameters between builds.

    • I was a top three finalist in the intern IdeaQuest competition with SmartBike, an IoT-connected bicycle.

  • Software Development Intern | Summer 2014

  • Epic Systems

    • Prototyped a web-based media-sharing application for radiologists.

▼ Research Experience:

  • I was awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship in 2018 for my work in NLP for low-resource languages.

  • U.S. Fulbright Scholar | Fall 2017 - Spring 2018

  • Hyderabad, India

    • Kelsey Ball, Dan Garrette. “Part-of-speech tagging for code-switched and transliterated text without explicit language identification.” In Proc. of EMNLP, 2018.

    • My host institution, IIIT-H, published an article about my experience.

  • Research Assistant | Fall 2014 - Fall 2015

  • University of Texas at Austin

    • Developed statistical models to analyze code-switching in bilingual speakers. Presented at two conferences on language contact and transfer.

    • The Undergraduate Research department at UT wrote a profile on my work.

▼ Teaching:

  • I have worked as a teaching assistant for two undergraduate courses and one study-abroad engineering course. I've also received a Teaching Award from the Cockrell School of Engineering.
  • Course Professor Semester
    EE319K Dr. Ramesh Yerraballi Spring 2014
    EE319K Dr. Mohit Tiwari Spring 2016
    EE306 Dr. Ramesh Yerraballi Fall 2016
    Embedded Systems and Industry in India Dr. Ramesh Yerraballi Summer 2016
